issues.title: SHA-1
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body: Is the plan to drop support for SHA-1 or just adding SHA-256?

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
I was thinking about just adding SHA-256, 
but if there were enough endorsement at WG, it might be nice to drop support for SHA-1.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
I would love to hear @CBonnell  and @clintwilson 's comments.
I believe, it would make less conflict to just add SHA-256.
In the other hand, if WG want to drop support for SHA-1, it is good.

I believe there should be lots of sha-1 certid used in the world, 
and not sure if we can have enough support to drop SHA-1. 

I prefer easier way to make document.

comments.author: CBonnell
comments.body:
[RFC 8954](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8954.html#name-nonce-extension) takes an interesting approach in mandating specific behavior for "newer OCSP clients":

>  Newer OCSP clients that support this document MUST use a length of 32 octets for the nonce in the Nonce extension.

The challenge with this approach is that "newer" is undefined, so it is not a strong requirement. But it does avoid the interoperability issue posed by the hash algorithm switch. Perhaps we could consider a similar approach here.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
It seems a good approach. 
RFC 8954 update 6960, and that section of 8954 describe  as "newer OCSP clients", contracting "with older clients that follow [RFC6960]".
It sounds like when it come to 6960 bis, it is going to be only new OCSP clients.

let me clarify if my understanding is correct.

with similar approach,  
we can let older "5019 supporting" clients support sha-1 only, and 
newer "5019-bis" supporting clients support sha-2 only ?  
In that approach, people who still want to use sha-1 can use old 5019 supporting client, but it sound OK for me.
(we may not obsolete 5019, but update 5019.)

Is it correct?

comments.author: CBonnell
comments.body: Yes, that's my understanding of the wording of RFC 8954 and how we can apply that convention to this document.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
@CBonnell 
would it work?
https://github.com/tadahik/RFC5019bis/blob/treatSHA1with8954approach/draft-bonnell-RFC5019.md

It seems like  now is the chance to submit this Draft
https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2022/12/nist-retires-sha-1-cryptographic-algorithm

@clintwilson 
my company is OK to publish I-D.
If Apple is OK for publishing, it might be good to publish this repo (and post I-D).

comments.author: clintwilson
comments.body: @tadahik Apple is ok to publish, but would require some additional internal review once finalized, so it may be more expedient to have you publish when ready.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body: @clintwilson I had a chat with Corey, and we agreed that it might be nice to publish after the holiday, and see reaction of lamps WG.

comments.body: @tadahik @clintwilson @CBonnell Let's make this change and merge #14 and get a version out so we can drop it on lamps?

issues.title: Figure out what to do about RFC 2560/6960 ResponderID byKey definition
issues.author: CBonnell
issues.body:
Both RFC 2560 and 6960 have this little gem in the ASN.1:

~~~
ResponderID ::= CHOICE {
   byName   [1] Name,
   byKey    [2] KeyHash }

KeyHash ::= OCTET STRING --SHA-1 hash of responder's public key
                         --(excluding the tag and length fields)
~~~

Unfortunately, I don't see another way to "override" this use of SHA-1 such that it could be understood by OCSP clients. I'm inclined to think we're stuck with this use of SHA-1, but I hope I'm wrong.

Thoughts?

comments.author: CBonnell
comments.body: It just dawned on me that we might be able to define the `byKey` value as the value of the responder certificate's (either direct or delegated signer) SKID extension. This would require that all OCSP delegated responder certs contain the SKID, but the inclusion of this extension is quite common and SKID generation method 1 of 5280 is commonly used, so this redefinition should have little real world impact.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
I confirmed use of SHA-1 in byKey. 
I am thinking that, our document is updating RFC5019, to fix conflict along with RFC 6960.
In the other hand, to change use of SHA-1 in byKey, we need to update RFC6960. 

For me, it seems it is more simple to publish this 5019bis as it is, and make new I-D(6960bis) to update 6960.
(As far as I understand, both 6960 and (overriding)6960bis  would not have conflict with 5019bis. )

comments.author: CBonnell
comments.body: Can we make our draft update both 5019 and 6960? There is precedent for that such as RFC 8996: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8996.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
I think we can update both 5019 and 6960 in one draft,  but I think it is better to divide.
I am not sure what Sean or Russ would say but in my understanding, 

- In 8996, there was strong consensus. but we do not have that strong consensus yet.
- 8996 updates many RFCs, but that is Best Current Practice paper and show changes in use of RFCs. we want to change standard track document itself. I think it make some difference.
- We still able to updates several standard track document together, but...
-- change of byKey (in 6960) might need some backward compatibility discussion, which tend to be long (unlike current draft) and can be very long.
-- updating 6960 might lead many work, and possibly need to work for additional unexpected indications.
-- some people may say we need to update more RFCs related with sha-1, which would also consume additional work again and again...

I believe, good way is marge 5019 to 6960 (now), then update 6960 with several RFCs, then marge those RFCs and make 6960bis. (to divide into  small steps, and we can focus into each step's discussion).

comments.author: CBonnell
comments.body:
Thanks for explaining the concern, @tadahik. You've convinced me that we should spin up another draft to address the `byKey` algorithm.

@clintwilson @seanturner do you agree with this approach?

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: To confirm you can definitely update more than one RFC with another, but I can already see the epic bikeshed about what to call the I-D ;) Splitting makes sense to me.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
I was making presentation slide for IETF117, and thinking about what would be goal for this draft.. 
https://github.com/tadahik/RFC5019bis/blob/117Presentation/117Presentation/IETF117Presentation.pptx

I believe, we can chose from 3 goal as following(I wrote in slide also), and I thought 1st option would work good. 
However, I am not sure if my understanding is correct, and we might be able to ask WG which one is good way to do.

- Allow use of SHA-256 for “High-Volume Environments”
-- Current Approach
-- OCSP responder/client will not use sha-256 after 6960-bis, but need sha-1 by then

- Do not require sha-1 for OCSP responder/client
-- need to update both 5019 and 6960
-- change definition of byKey of responderID from sha-1 to sha-256
-- may cause interoperability issue for non-5019 client and responder.

- Do not require sha-1 for OCSP responder/client for “High-Volume Environments”
-- How to calculate responderID? is problem
-- calculate byKey of of responderID to sha256?  >> conflict with RFC6960
-- Do not calculate with sha-1, but refer SKID  >> interoperable with RFC 6960
-- require that all OCSP delegated responder certs contain the SKID

Any suggestion?

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body: 3rd option may not need to update 6960. it seems similar to 6277 and make it something like "Online Certificate Status Protocol Algorithm  Agility for High-Volume Environment"... but still not quite sure about how people would think use of SKID..

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body: 6960 is general profile, and 5019 is high volume env profile, so I believe it is fine that 5019-bis depend on 6960, but changing 6960 for 5019 seems more interoperability problem.

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
@CBonnell 
Hi I updated slide, 
![overview of 5019bis](https://github.com/tadahik/RFC5019bis/blob/117Presentation/117Presentation/5019-%20bis.png)

I was thinking that there would be two important potential question. 
could you confirm that we are in same view, or if i am lacking something.
(or I am writing to much, which I had better not to talk at WG )

[Q]Why you do not marge and make 6960-bis?
[A]We believe it is great to make 6960-bis, however, 
- 5019-bis is about profile on high-voulume environments, but 6960-bis is about general  protocol, they are quite different. in addition, 6960-bis would take much longer to process. 
- 6960-bis would have many other discussion apart from SHA-1 issue

[Q]Why you do not marge change on responderID to the draft?
[A]We can, but with following reason, we prefer to separate
- Migrations of a profile and a protocol tend to be different
- Scope of migration / backward compatibility would be much broader for 6960-bis
- Some solution might cause some problem to state ASN.1 module

@clintwilson 
Hi client, In current approach of 5019-bis, we would able to migrate SHA-1 certID to SHA-2 CertID relatively faster, 
but would need another internet-draft to move from SHA-1 responderID to SHA-2 responderID. is it OK? 

I believe we (authors) do not have consensus of moving to SHA-2 responderID.
Do you think you would endorsee migration of SHA-1 responderID to SHA-2 ResponderID? 
so far i agree that migration also, and it might be good chance to discuss on the WG.

( I believe Corey's idea of using SKID is good, but not sure about potential issues on implementation and ASN.1 module.)

comments.author: clintwilson
comments.body:
Hey @tadahik, I think this approach seems good and indeed my focus has been on the restriction 5019 places on certID, disallowing use of anything but SHA-1. Removing that restriction is (or should be), I think, a relatively straightforward case to make to the WG and one upon which I think broad consensus can be built.

Beyond that there are a whole slew of other updates (minor and major) these documents can benefit from, however those benefits are also balanced against ecosystem reliance, use, and support of OCSP. Currently OCSP is heavily relied upon, but we're moving fairly quickly towards a time where it's used, but not relied upon. I expect some time will pass in that state, but we may then end up with OCSP being supported and not used. Finally, support could be dropped, at which point many of the updates we're talking about may not ultimately be worthwhile.

Which is to say, once we start looking at larger updates to these RFCs, I think we maybe need to look even bigger -- much bigger. How can OCSP be privacy-preserving by default? How can it scale to real-world use-cases evolved over the last decade? What has contributed to OCSP-stapling's adoption remaining insignificant on internet-scale? What has contributed to OCSP becoming optional in the CA/BF? Is it worth the effort to address these issues and "fix" OCSP, or would time be better spent standardizing something else (CRL coalescing technologies as one possibility)?

comments.author: tadahik
comments.body:
@clintwilson 
Thanks Clint, You gave us great points, and also...

> Currently OCSP is heavily relied upon, but we're moving fairly quickly towards a time where it's used, but not relied upon. 
> I expect some time will pass in that state, but we may then end up with OCSP being supported and not used

I just thought, it is very good point for focusing CertID, but not for responderID.
CertID may be able to be useful for other revocation mechanism, because  you can identify the certificate. 
In the other hand, responderID would be much less useful in that perspective.

Now I thing I would be much more comfortable to defend statement of focus on just SHA-1 on CertID.

comments.author: CBonnell
tadahik
comments.body:
Thanks @CBonnell 
> work on finalizing it this weekend in San Francisco.... third option to slide 4,...

Good Ideas, I will see you in San Francisco.

comments.body:
We explained difference on profile(RFC5019) and protocol(6960), and we are just changing profile.

pulls.title: First stab at addressing Russ's suggestions (#23)
pulls.author: CBonnell

comments.body: If we're making "byKey" support MTI, then we also have to make responders use byKey, otherwise there may be interoperability issues.

This description seem fine for me.

I just noticed below difference.
> OCSPResponses that conform to this profile SHOULD include only one SingleResponse

> Newer responders that conform to this document

I am not sure but I think we do not distinguish “this profile” and “this document”,
so we may use profile instead of document.
Thanks @tadahik. I just pushed a commit that changes all usages of "document" to "profile".
Does this need to be a 2119 SHOULD?

I used the lowercase form of "should", since that's what we do for the CertID language: https://github.com/tadahik/RFC5019bis/pull/30/files#diff-7dea5da080403877cd9d2f68885a566da401b61d9b19bacfce6afc3e1188f1f5R140.

I suppose I'm conflicted whether to use uppercase or lowercase here, since migrations are not really part of the protocol being defined by the document. That being said, it would be useful to provide guidance that we recommend such a migration.

Thoughts on which way to go?
That rationale makes sense to me, so keeping it as lowercase seems right.

pulls.author: tadahik
pulls.body:
1) rename draft-bonnell... to draft-ietf-lamps-rfc...

2) Addressed Rob's comment.
<https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/OWDDnWVnSrCq27n5qSQk9nBiS9c/>

> I favour option #2, if it's found to be widely compatible with existing clients.
To address that point, and add "For instance..."

>> We may mention this use of User-Agent sniffing to determine client capabilities in passing in the draft.
> Good idea.
It seems not profile matter, but protocol matter, so I did not made change.


3) Addressed Russ's comment
<https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/qtTbW5DPDMbYqDJ5h8CGMxn1QMM/>

looks good to me

I also confirmed every section number in this document, including section 4 of RFC4648
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4648#section-4

comments.body:
```suggestion
responder MAY include two SingleResponses in a BasicOCSPResponse.
```

```suggestion
In that BasicOCSPResponse, the CertID of one of the SingleResponses uses SHA-1 for the hash
```

pulls.title: Update draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5019bis.md
pulls.author: tadahik
pulls.body: fix a nit for BasicOCSPResponse

pulls.title: address comments on WGLC(02Draft)
pulls.author: tadahik
pulls.body:
Addressed Rob’s comment with Tim, Russ comment
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/Bk-0_zas5PTqL-us0JDv8fyQQWQ/
- remove SHALL NOT
- move two SingleResponse sentence to profile section with explicitly mention about backward compatibility

Addressed Rich’s comment
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/cu1gJwy2kxHqxrjGwarA5kPs3lo/
- List the terms that come from ASN.1 of 5019/6960 
- with the fact of some environment allow a day of leeway, so add “(e.g. allow one day difference)”
- add "HTTP-based OCSP requests can use either the GET or the POST method to submit their requests."

Add possibility of logging requests to check how much SHA-1 is used for Client’s CertID, and use that information to determine when to stop SHA-1 support.

pulls.body: change number of whitespaces for indents

pulls.title: Fix reference to SHA-1 sec con
pulls.author: CBonnell

pulls.title: Addressed IESG evaluation
pulls.author: tadahik
pulls.body:
addressed comments in
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5019bis/ballot/


# Deb
> Section 3.2.2, Appendix A:  The two terms 'byName' and 'byKey' are used without being defined 

- Line 310, regarding with Russ's comments

# Gunter

> unclear what the 'but only' refers towards...

- addressed in Line 71
- addressed in Line 76

> simpler to say 'in highly scaled PKI environments'

- addressed in Line 108

# Orie

> Section 1 profile discovery

- Change "will" to "may" in Line 124
- will add example of shared policies

> sha-1 still ok?

- change to MUST on Line 183

> Section 3.1.1 missing Signature

- addressed Line 144, Line 208 with slight difference (withdraw one "relevant")

> Section 3.1.1 which AlgorithmIdentifier is used for SHA-256? 

- change ref to RFC5754, line 176

> Section 3.1.2 ignore requestorName?

- addressed in Line 201

> Section 3.2.4 redundant MUST?

- clarify with change from Line 356

> 8.5.  Modification of HTTP Headers is ok?

- call out 6960 section 4.2.2.1 in Line 680

> Section 8.3 capitalize must

- addressed in Line 644

> 8.4.  Denial-of-Service Attacks

- addressed in line 664

> Section 3.1.1 DN expand on first use

- addressed in line 174

# Eric Vyncke

> Section 3.1.1

- addresssed Line 170, 183

> Section 3.1.2

- Line 201

> Section 3.2.2

- addressed in Line 289

> Section 7.3

- addressed. also changed server to responder in several place

# other changes

- fix references (change normative to informative, add section numbers for some of them)

- Line 366, refer RFC6960 section 2.5, clarify thisUpdate and producedAt are not always same, regarding with private comment.
